article.headline: Air Force 68, New Mexico 42
article.story: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) -- A new era has arrived at Air Force. The Falcons, who haven't had a winning season in 26 years, finished off a momentous week with a 68-42 win over New Mexico on Saturday night, the Falcons' first win in Albuquerque in 42 years. Sophomore center Nick Welch scored 18 points, including four straight 3-pointers in the second half as the Falcons got their school record ninth straight win -- a modest winning streak at a lot of other Division I programs, but a significant milestone for a school that hasn't had a winning season since 1978. "We're a different team now and hopefully people want to talk about how good we're going to be and how good we're getting," Welch said. "They're not talking about how bad we used to be." Air Force (11-2, 2-0 MWC) thoroughly outplayed New Mexico to get its first victory ever in The Pit, snapping an 0-for-22 streak in the arena built in 1966. The Falcons had not won in Albuquerque since Feb. 7, 1962, when they beat New Mexico at Johnson Gymnasium. The victory was the second high note of the week for Air Force, who on Monday snapped a 27-game road losing streak in Mountain West Conference play with a 65-57 win at Colorado State. "I think we've gotten to the point where all those things, 22 in The Pit, 42 (in Albuquerque), none of our guys were around for that stuff," said Falcons fourth-year coach Joe Scott. "We won 12 games last year and part of building a program is getting better every year," Scott said. "All those things that were around our program in the past are gone and now it's just about whose players are playing better." New Mexico (9-6, 0-2), led only once and had no defense for the Falcons' prolific 3-point shooting and tough defense, which held the Lobos to a season-low point total. The Falcons lead the nation in scoring defense, giving up just 47.3 points a game. Danny Granger with 15 points was the only New Mexico player in double figures. New Mexico coach Ritchie McKay took responsibility for the Lobos' second worst conference loss ever in The Pit. "To play like that is very embarrassing," McKay said. "I'm at blame for the loss because the defense we tried to implement didn't work." McKay is in his second season at New Mexico. The Lobos finished 10-18 last year, their worst season in 23 years, and McKay caught plenty of heat from Lobo fans Saturday as the Falcons turned the game into a rout. "All the things you guys (media) want to write tomorrow, I'm certainly deserving of," McKay said. "I got out-coached and all your speculation about whether I'm the guy for the job I'll take on my shoulders." Seven Falcons hit 3-pointers, with Air Force going 12-for-20 from behind the arc. Air Force, which has held every opponent under 25 points in the first half, built a 34-23 lead at halftime. The Falcons took control with an 11-0 run that included three straight 3s from Jacob Burtschi, Tim Keller and Matt McGraw. Then Welch took over in the second half. Left alone at the top of the key, the 6-foot-8 sophomore swished in four 3s that put the Falcons ahead 55-30 with 8:45 left. Welch accentuated each 3-pointer by seeming to pose, his right hand high about his head. Welch said he's been working on his shooting with help from assistant coach Chris Mooney. "He always told me it's just like shooting in the park," Welch said. "They didn't seem to guard me in the second half and it's even easier whenever it's a wide open look." The New Mexico fans, who booed the Falcons through the first 30 minutes, turned their jeers on the Lobos, who also had 17 turnovers, shot 37 percent and hit just three of 15 3-point attempts. "We didn't get stops, we didn't have any patience offensively in our execution, we had 17 turnovers against a team that doesn't pressure and we didn't play good transition basketball. We didn't box out and weren't very good one-on-one defensively," McKay said. New Mexico, playing before its first sellout crowd of 18,018 in more than two years, got its only lead on a 3-pointer by Troy DeVries in the game's opening minute. Air Force answered with eight straight points, six of them by Joel Gerlach.
